# iPad

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the line of tablet computers by Apple Inc. For type of
[mobile computer](/wiki/Mobile_computer "Mobile computer"), see [Tablet
computer](/wiki/Tablet_computer "Tablet computer"). For other uses, see [iPad
(disambiguation)](/wiki/IPad_\(disambiguation\) "IPad \(disambiguation\)").

**iPad** ([/ˈaɪpæd/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [_**EYE**
-pad_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling
key")) is a line of [tablet computers](/wiki/Tablet_computer "Tablet
computer") designed, developed and marketed by [Apple Inc.](/wiki/Apple_Inc.
"Apple Inc."), which run the [iOS](/wiki/IOS "IOS") mobile operating system.
The first iPad was released on April 3, 2010; the most recent iPad models are
the [iPad (2017)](/wiki/IPad_\(2017\) "IPad \(2017\)"), released on March 24,
2017, the 10.5-inch (270 mm) and 12.9-inch (330 mm) 2G [iPad
Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro") released on June 13, 2017. The [user
interface](/wiki/User_interface "User interface") is built around the device's
[multi-touch](/wiki/Multi-touch "Multi-touch") screen, including a [virtual
keyboard](/wiki/Virtual_keyboard "Virtual keyboard"). All iPads can connect
via [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi"); some models also have
[cellular](/wiki/Cellular_network "Cellular network") connectivity.

As of January 2015, Apple had sold more than 250 million iPads[6], though
sales peaked in 2013[17][18] and it is now the second-most popular kind of
tablet computer, by sales, after [Android](/wiki/Android_\(operating_system\)
"Android \(operating system\)")-based types.[19]

An iPad can [shoot video](/wiki/Video_camera "Video camera"), [take
photos](/wiki/Camera_phone "Camera phone"), [play
music](/wiki/Portable_media_player "Portable media player"), and perform
Internet functions such as web-browsing and emailing. Other functions –
[games](/wiki/Video_game "Video game"), [reference](/wiki/Reference_work
"Reference work"), [GPS navigation](/wiki/GPS_navigation_software "GPS
navigation software"), [social networking](/wiki/Social_networking_service
"Social networking service"), etc. – can be enabled by downloading and
installing [apps](/wiki/Application_software "Application software"). As of
March 2016, the [App Store](/wiki/App_Store_\(iOS\) "App Store \(iOS\)") has
more than one million apps for the iPad by Apple and third parties.

There have been seven [versions](/wiki/List_of_iOS_devices#iPad "List of iOS
devices") of the iPad. The [first generation](/wiki/IPad_\(first_generation\)
"IPad \(first generation\)") established design precedents, some of which,
such as the home button placement, have persisted through all models. The
[2nd-generation iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(2nd_generation\) "IPad \(2nd generation\)")
(iPad 2) introduced a new thinner design, a [dual-core](/wiki/Multi-
core_processor "Multi-core processor") [Apple A5](/wiki/Apple_A5 "Apple A5")
processor, and VGA front-facing and [720p](/wiki/720p "720p") rear-facing
cameras designed for [FaceTime](/wiki/FaceTime "FaceTime") video calling. The
[third generation](/wiki/IPad_\(third_generation\) "IPad \(third
generation\)") added a [Retina Display](/wiki/Retina_Display "Retina
Display"), the new [Apple A5X](/wiki/Apple_A5X "Apple A5X") processor with a
[quad-core](/wiki/Multi-core_processor "Multi-core processor") [graphics
processor](/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit "Graphics processing unit"), a
5-[megapixel](/wiki/Megapixel "Megapixel") camera, HD [1080p](/wiki/1080p
"1080p") video recording, [voice dictation](/wiki/Digital_dictation "Digital
dictation"), and [4G](/wiki/4G "4G") ([LTE](/wiki/3GPP_Long_Term_Evolution
"3GPP Long Term Evolution")). The [fourth
generation](/wiki/IPad_\(fourth_generation\) "IPad \(fourth generation\)")
added the [Apple A6X](/wiki/Apple_A6X "Apple A6X") processor and replaced the
[30-pin connector](/wiki/30-pin_dock_connector#Apple_30-pin_dock_connector
"30-pin dock connector") with an all-digital [Lightning
connector](/wiki/Lightning_\(connector\) "Lightning \(connector\)"). The [iPad
Air](/wiki/IPad_Air "IPad Air") added the [Apple A7](/wiki/Apple_A7 "Apple
A7") processor and the [Apple M7](/wiki/Apple_M7 "Apple M7") motion
coprocessor, and reduced the thickness for the first time since the iPad 2.
The [iPad Air 2](/wiki/IPad_Air_2 "IPad Air 2") added the [Apple
A8X](/wiki/Apple_A8X "Apple A8X") processor, the [Apple M8](/wiki/Apple_M8
"Apple M8") [motion coprocessor](/wiki/Apple_motion_coprocessors "Apple motion
coprocessors"), an 8-megapixel camera, and the [Touch ID](/wiki/Touch_ID
"Touch ID") [fingerprint sensor](/wiki/Fingerprint_recognition "Fingerprint
recognition"); and further reduced the thickness. The
[iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(2017\) "IPad \(2017\)") introduced in 2017 added the
[Apple A9](/wiki/Apple_A9 "Apple A9") processor, while sacrificing some of the
improvements the iPad Air 2 introduced in exchange for a lower launch price.

There have been four [versions](/wiki/List_of_iOS_devices#iPad_Mini "List of
iOS devices") of the [iPad Mini](/wiki/IPad_Mini "IPad Mini"), all of which
have a screen size of 7.9 inches (20 cm). The [first
generation](/wiki/IPad_Mini_\(first_generation\) "IPad Mini \(first
generation\)") has similar internal specifications as the iPad 2 but uses the
[Lightning connector](/wiki/Lightning_\(connector\) "Lightning \(connector\)")
instead. The [iPad Mini 2](/wiki/IPad_Mini_2 "IPad Mini 2") added the [Retina
Display](/wiki/Retina_Display "Retina Display"), the [Apple A7](/wiki/Apple_A7
"Apple A7") processor, and the [Apple M7](/wiki/Apple_M7 "Apple M7") [motion
coprocessor](/wiki/Apple_motion_coprocessors "Apple motion coprocessors"),
closely matching the internal specifications of the iPad Air. The [iPad Mini
3](/wiki/IPad_Mini_3 "IPad Mini 3") added the [Touch ID](/wiki/Touch_ID "Touch
ID") fingerprint sensor. The [iPad Mini 4](/wiki/IPad_Mini_4 "IPad Mini 4")
features the [Apple A8](/wiki/Apple_A8 "Apple A8") and the [Apple
M8](/wiki/Apple_M8 "Apple M8") motion coprocessor.

There have been two [generations](/wiki/List_of_iOS_devices#iPad_Pro "List of
iOS devices") of the [iPad Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro"). The first
generation came with 9.7" and 12.9" screen sizes, while the second came with
10.5" and 12.9" sizes. The iPad Pros have unique features such as the Smart
Connector and the ability to use the [Apple Pencil](/wiki/Apple_Pencil "Apple
Pencil") stylus, which are exclusive to this series of iPads.

## History

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Steve_Jobs_with_the_Apple_iPad_no_logo_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-
Steve_Jobs_with_the_Apple_iPad_no_logo_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Steve_Jobs_with_the_Apple_iPad_no_logo_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Steve_Jobs_with_the_Apple_iPad_no_logo_\(cropped\).jpg
"Enlarge")

[Steve Jobs](/wiki/Steve_Jobs "Steve Jobs"), Apple's then CEO, introducing the
iPad.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Apple_Newton-
IMG_0454-cropped.jpg/170px-Apple_Newton-
IMG_0454-cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Newton-IMG_0454-cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Apple_Newton-IMG_0454-cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

Apple's first tablet from 1993

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/cc67377568e767dba4cf41268dd5828f.png)

Apple co-founder [Steve Jobs](/wiki/Steve_Jobs "Steve Jobs") said in a 1983
speech[20] that the company's

> strategy is really simple. What we want to do is we want to put an
> incredibly great computer in a book that you can carry around with you and
> learn how to use in 20 minutes ... and we really want to do it with a radio
> link in it so you don’t have to hook up to anything and you’re in
> communication with all of these larger databases and other computers.

Apple's first tablet computer was the [Newton](/wiki/Newton_\(platform\)
"Newton \(platform\)") [MessagePad 100](/wiki/MessagePad
"MessagePad"),[21][22] introduced in 1993, powered by an
[ARM6](/wiki/ARM_architecture "ARM architecture") processor core developed by
[ARM](/wiki/ARM_Limited "ARM Limited"), a 1990 spinout of [Acorn
Computers](/wiki/Acorn_Computers "Acorn Computers") in which Apple invested.
Apple also developed a prototype [PowerBook Duo](/wiki/PowerBook_Duo
"PowerBook Duo") based tablet, the [PenLite](/wiki/PowerBook_Duo#PenLite
"PowerBook Duo"), but decided not to sell it in order to avoid hurting
MessagePad sales.[23] Apple released several more Newton-based PDAs; the final
one, the [MessagePad 2100](/wiki/MessagePad "MessagePad"), was discontinued in
1998.

Apple re-entered the mobile-computing markets in 2007 with the
[iPhone](/wiki/IPhone "IPhone"). Smaller than the iPad, but featuring a camera
and mobile phone, it pioneered the [multi-touch](/wiki/Multi-touch "Multi-
touch") finger-sensitive touchscreen interface of Apple's [iOS](/wiki/IOS
"IOS") mobile [operating system](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system").
By late 2009, the iPad's release had been rumored for several years. Such
speculation mostly talked about "Apple's tablet"; specific names included
_iTablet_ and _iSlate_.[24] The iPad was announced on January 27, 2010, by
Steve Jobs at an Apple press conference at the [Yerba Buena Center for the
Arts](/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Center_for_the_Arts "Yerba Buena Center for the Arts")
in San Francisco.[25][26]

Jobs later said that Apple had begun developing the iPad before the
iPhone.[27][28] [Jonathan Ive](/wiki/Jonathan_Ive "Jonathan Ive") in 1991 had
created an industrial design for a stylus-based tablet, the Macintosh Folio,
as his first project for Apple; by 2004 his studio at the company was
participating in the development of a large tablet prototype, which he later
described as "very crude, involving projectors". Ive stated that after seeking
to produce the tablet first, he came to agree with Jobs that the phone was
more important,[29] as the tablet's innovations would work as well in it.[30]
The iPad's internal codename was K48, which was revealed in the court case
surrounding leaking of iPad information before launch.[31]

Apple began taking pre-orders for the [first-
generation](/wiki/IPad_\(first_generation\) "IPad \(first generation\)") iPad
on March 12, 2010.[2] The only major change to the device between its
announcement and being available to pre-order was the change of the behavior
of the side switch to perform either sound muting or screen rotation locking
(user selectable).[32] The Wi-Fi version of the iPad went on sale in the
United States on April 3, 2010.[2][33] The Wi-Fi + 3G version was released on
April 30.[2][3][3] 3G service in the United States is provided by
[AT&T](/wiki/AT%26T_Mobility "AT&T Mobility") and was initially sold with two
prepaid contract-free data plan options: one for unlimited data and the other
for 250 MB per month at half the price.[34][35] On June 2, 2010, AT&T
announced that effective June 7 the unlimited plan would be replaced for new
customers with a 2 GB plan at slightly lower cost; existing customers would
have the option to keep the unlimited plan.[36] The plans are activated on the
iPad itself and can be cancelled at any time.[37]

Initially, the iPad was only available to order at the [Apple
Store](/wiki/Apple_Store "Apple Store"), but has since become available for
purchase through retailers including Amazon, Walmart, and network operators.
The iPad was launched in countries including Australia, Canada, France,
Germany, Japan and the United Kingdom on May 28.[38][39] Online pre-orders in
those countries began on May 10.[3] Apple released the iPad in [Hong
Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand and
[Singapore](/wiki/Singapore "Singapore") on July 23, 2010.[40][41][42] Israel
briefly prohibited importation of the iPad because of concerns that its Wi-Fi
might interfere with other devices.[43] On September 17, 2010, the iPad was
officially launched in China.[44]

300,000 iPads were sold on their first day of availability.[45] By May 3,
2010, Apple had sold a million iPads;[46] this was in half the time it took
Apple to sell the same number of first-generation iPhones.[47] After passing
the one million mark they continued selling rapidly reaching 3 million sales
after 80 days.[48] During the October 18, 2010, financial conference call,
Steve Jobs announced that Apple had sold more iPads than Macs for the fiscal
quarter.[49] In total, Apple sold more than 15 million first-generation iPads
prior to the launch of the iPad 2[50] – selling more than all other tablet PCs
combined since the iPad's release.[51] and reaching 75% of tablet PC sales at
the end of 2010.[52]

Jobs unveiled the [iPad 2](/wiki/IPad_2 "IPad 2") at a March 2, 2011, press
conference.[53][54] About 33% thinner than its predecessor and 15% lighter,
the iPad 2 has a better processor, a [dual core](/wiki/Dual_core "Dual core")
[Apple A5](/wiki/Apple_A5 "Apple A5") that Apple says is twice as fast as its
predecessor for CPU operations and up to nine times as fast for GPU
operations. The iPad 2 includes front and back cameras that support the
[FaceTime](/wiki/FaceTime "FaceTime") [videophone](/wiki/Videophone
"Videophone") application, as well as a three-axis [gyroscope](/wiki/Gyroscope
"Gyroscope"). It retained the original's 10‑hour battery life and had a
similar pricing scheme.

The successor to the iPad 2 was unveiled on March 7, 2012, by Apple CEO [Tim
Cook](/wiki/Tim_Cook "Tim Cook") at the [Yerba Buena Center for the
Arts](/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Center_for_the_Arts "Yerba Buena Center for the
Arts").[55][56] [The new iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(third_generation\) "IPad \(third
generation\)") contained a new [dual core](/wiki/Multi-core_processor "Multi-
core processor") A5X processor with quad-core graphics, and a [Retina
Display](/wiki/Retina_Display "Retina Display") with a resolution of 2048 by
1536 pixels,[57] more than 50 percent more pixels than a standard 1,920 by
1,080 [high definition TV screen](/wiki/High-definition_television#High-
definition_display_resolutions "High-definition television"). A brief
controversy erupted when it was revealed that the LTE advertised did not work
in some countries.[58]

On October 23, 2012, Apple announced the [fourth generation
iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(fourth_generation\) "IPad \(fourth generation\)"), which
began shipping on November 2, 2012. The new hardware includes an
[A6X](/wiki/Apple_A6 "Apple A6") processor, HD FaceTime camera, improved LTE
compatibility, and the all-digital [Lightning](/wiki/Lightning_\(connector\)
"Lightning \(connector\)") connector. It is available in the same storage
increments and pricing structure as the third generation.[59][60] Following
the announcement of the fourth-generation iPad, the previous generation was
discontinued.

Alongside the launch of the fourth generation hardware, Apple announced the
[iPad Mini](/wiki/IPad_Mini "IPad Mini"). With a screen measuring 7.9 inches,
it is aimed at the emerging sector of [smaller tablets](/wiki/Mini_tablets
"Mini tablets") such as the [Kindle Fire](/wiki/Kindle_Fire "Kindle Fire") and
[Nexus 7](/wiki/Nexus_7_\(2012_version\) "Nexus 7 \(2012 version\)"). The
hardware of the new iPad Mini is similar to the [iPad 2](/wiki/IPad_2 "IPad
2"), with a 1024 by 768 pixel resolution screen and a dual core
[A5](/wiki/Apple_A5 "Apple A5") processor, but is 53% lighter and 7.2 mm
thick. It was released on November 2, 2012, in 16 GB, 32 GB, and 64 GB
capacities and WiFi or Wi‑Fi + Cellular versions.[60]

On October 22, 2013, Apple introduced the fifth generation of iPad, called the
[iPad Air](/wiki/IPad_Air "IPad Air"), and the second generation of iPad Mini,
called [iPad Mini 2](/wiki/IPad_Mini_2 "IPad Mini 2") that comes with a
[Retina Display](/wiki/Retina_Display "Retina Display"). The iPad Air went on
sale on November 1, 2013, starting at $499, while the iPad Mini 2 was released
on November 12, 2013, starting at $399.

In the first quarter of 2014, Apple reported that it had sold 25 million
iPads, an all-time quarterly record, compared to 22.9 million in the year-ago
quarter.[61][62]

In October 2014, Apple released the [iPad Air 2](/wiki/IPad_Air_2 "IPad Air
2") and the [iPad Mini 3](/wiki/IPad_Mini_3 "IPad Mini 3"). The iPad Air 2 is
the first iOS device to feature a triple core CPU and 2GB of RAM. As well as
being thinner and faster than its predecessor, the iPad Air, it features
[Touch ID](/wiki/Touch_ID "Touch ID") and is available with a gold color
option. The iPad Mini 3 is similar than the iPad Mini 2 in design and
hardware, but also includes Touch ID and available in gold color.

In September 2015, the [iPad Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro") was announced,
which included a 12.9-inch screen,[63] and a 9.7-inch version was announced in
March 2016, with the addition of 256 GB option for both iPad Pro
models.[64][65]

On March 21, 2017, a new [iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(2017\) "IPad \(2017\)") was
announced. The hardware includes an [A9](/wiki/Apple_A9 "Apple A9") processor
and is designed to be a budget version of the iPad.[66]

In June 2017, the iPad Pro's second generation hardware was announced to have
12.9 and 10.5-inch screens.[67]

## Hardware

### Screen and input

The iPad's (first two generations) [touchscreen](/wiki/Touchscreen
"Touchscreen") display is a 1024 by 768 pixel, 7.75×5.82 in (197×148 mm)
[liquid-crystal display](/wiki/Liquid-crystal_display "Liquid-crystal
display") (diagonal 9.7 in (246.4 mm)), with
[fingerprint-](/wiki/Lipophobicity "Lipophobicity") and scratch-resistant
glass. Steve Jobs said a 7-inch screen would be "too small to express the
software" and that 10 inches was the minimum for a tablet screen.[68] Like the
iPhone, the iPad is designed to be controlled by bare fingers; normal, non-
conductive gloves and [styli](/wiki/Stylus "Stylus") do not work,[69] although
there are special gloves and [capacitive styli](/wiki/Capacitive_stylus
"Capacitive stylus") designed for this use.[70][71]

The display responds to other sensors: an ambient light sensor to adjust
screen brightness and a 3-axis [accelerometer](/wiki/Accelerometer
"Accelerometer") to sense iPad orientation and switch between [portrait and
landscape](/wiki/Page_orientation "Page orientation") modes. Unlike the iPhone
and iPod Touch's built-in applications, which work in three orientations
(portrait, landscape-left and landscape-right), the iPad's built-in
applications support [screen rotation](/wiki/Screen_rotation "Screen
rotation") in all four orientations, including upside-down. Consequently, the
device has no intrinsic "native" orientation; only the relative position of
the home button changes.[72]

There are four physical switches on the iPad, including a home button near the
display that returns the user to the main menu, and three plastic physical
switches on the sides: _wake/sleep_ and _volume up/down_ , plus a software-
controlled switch whose function has changed with software updates. Originally
the switch locked the screen to its current orientation, but the iOS 4.2
changed it to a mute switch, with rotation lock now available in an onscreen
menu.[73] In the iOS 4.3 update, released with the iPad 2, a setting was added
to allow the user to specify whether the side switch was used for rotation
lock or mute.[13]

The first generation iPad had no camera; the iPad 2 has a front
[VGA](/wiki/VGA "VGA") camera and a rear-facing [720p](/wiki/720p "720p")
camera, both capable of still images (but these are only taken at a low
quality 0.3 megapixels) and 30[fps](/wiki/Frame_rate "Frame rate") video. The
rear-facing camera has a 5× [digital zoom](/wiki/Digital_zoom "Digital zoom")
for still images only. Both shoot photo and video in a [4:3](/wiki/4:3 "4:3")
fullscreen aspect ratio, unlike the [iPhone 4](/wiki/IPhone_4 "IPhone 4"),
which shoots in a [16:9](/wiki/16:9 "16:9") widescreen aspect ratio. Unlike
the iPhone, the iPad does not support tap to focus, but does allow a tap to
set auto exposure.[74] The cameras allow [FaceTime](/wiki/FaceTime "FaceTime")
video messaging with iPhone 4, fourth generation iPod Touch, and [Snow
Leopard](/wiki/Mac_OS_X_Snow_Leopard "Mac OS X Snow Leopard"),
[Lion](/wiki/Mac_OS_X_Lion "Mac OS X Lion"), and [Mountain
Lion](/wiki/OS_X_Mountain_Lion "OS X Mountain Lion") [Macs](/wiki/Macintosh
"Macintosh").[75]

### Audio and output

The iPad has two internal speakers reproducing left and right channel audio
located on the bottom-right of the unit. In the original iPad, the speakers
push sound through two small sealed channels leading to the three audio ports
carved into the device,[14] while the iPad 2 has its speakers behind a single
grill.[9] A volume switch is on the right side of the unit. A 3.5-mm [TRRS
connector](/wiki/Phone_connector_\(audio\) "Phone connector \(audio\)") audio-
out jack on the top-left corner of the device provides stereo sound for
headphones with or without microphones and/or volume controls. The iPad also
contains a microphone that can be used for [voice
recording](/wiki/Sound_recording_and_reproduction "Sound recording and
reproduction").

The built-in [Bluetooth 2.1 + EDR](/wiki/Bluetooth_2.1 "Bluetooth 2.1")
interface allows wireless headphones and keyboards to be used with the
iPad.[76] However iOS does not currently support [file
transfer](/wiki/Bluetooth_protocols#Object_exchange_\(OBEX\) "Bluetooth
protocols") via Bluetooth.[77] iPad also features 1024×768 VGA video output
for limited applications,[78] screen capture,[79] connecting an external
display or television through an accessory adapter.

### Battery

The iPad uses an internal [rechargeable](/wiki/Rechargeable_battery
"Rechargeable battery") [lithium-ion polymer](/wiki/Lithium-ion_polymer
"Lithium-ion polymer") (LiPo) battery. The batteries are made in
[Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") by Simplo Technology (60%) and Dynapack
International Technology.[80] The iPad is designed to be charged with a high
current of 2 amperes using the included 10 W USB power adapter and USB cord
with a USB connector at one end and a 30-pin dock connector at the other end.
While it can be charged by a standard USB port from a computer, these are
limited to 500 milliamperes (0.5 amps). As a result, if the iPad is running
while powered by a normal USB computer port, it may charge very slowly, or not
at all. High-power USB ports found in newer Apple computers and accessories
provide full charging capabilities.[81]

Apple claims that the battery for both generations of iPad can provide up to
10 hours of video, 140 hours of audio playback, or one month on standby. Like
any rechargeable battery technology, the iPad's battery loses capacity over
time, but is not designed to be user-replaceable. In a program similar to the
battery-replacement program for the [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod") and the original
iPhone, Apple will replace an iPad that does not hold an electrical charge
with a refurbished iPad for a fee of US$99 plus $6.95 shipping.[82][83] As a
different unit is supplied, user data is not preserved. The refurbished unit
will have a new case.[84] The warranty on the refurbished unit may vary
between jurisdictions.

Independent companies also provide a battery replacement service, returning
the original unit with new battery but original case. Alternatively it is
possible for a technically competent user to buy and install a new battery.
The task does not require soldering, but is technically challenging.[85]

### Storage

The iPad was released with three capacity options for storage: 16, 32, or 64
GB of internal [flash memory](/wiki/Flash_memory "Flash memory"). On January
29, 2013, Apple announced a 128 GB model of the [fourth generation
iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(fourth_generation\) "IPad \(fourth generation\)"), which
was released on February 5.[12] All data is stored on the internal flash
memory, with no option to expand storage. Apple sells a "camera connection
kit" with an [SD card](/wiki/SD_card "SD card") reader, but it can only be
used to transfer photos and videos.[86] On March 21, 2016, Apple announced a
256 GB model of the [iPad Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro"), which was released
on March 31. In 2017, Apple released a 10.5-inch iPad Pro and a revised
12.9-inch iPad Pro with a 512 GB option, the first of its kind on an iOS
device.

### Cellular connectivity

iPad models come in two basic variants: Wi-Fi only and Wi-Fi with cellular
support. The cellular variants however do not support circuit-switched voice
calls and texts, only data connectivity. The side of the [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi
"Wi-Fi") \+ [3G](/wiki/3G "3G") iPad had a [micro-
SIM](/wiki/Subscriber_identity_module#Card_sizes "Subscriber identity module")
slot (not [mini-SIM](/wiki/Subscriber_identity_module "Subscriber identity
module")). The 3G iPad can be used with any compatible [GSM](/wiki/GSM "GSM")
carrier, unlike the iPhone, which is usually sold ['locked' to specific
carriers](/wiki/SIM_lock "SIM lock").[87] On the first generations of the iPad
in the U.S., data network access via [T-Mobile](/wiki/T-Mobile_US "T-Mobile
US")'s network was limited to slower
[EDGE](/wiki/Enhanced_Data_Rates_for_GSM_Evolution "Enhanced Data Rates for
GSM Evolution") cellular speeds because T-Mobile's 3G Network at the time used
different frequencies.[88][89]

The [second generation iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(2nd_generation\) "IPad \(2nd
generation\)") introduced a third tier of models with [CDMA](/wiki/CDMA
"CDMA") support for [Verizon Wireless](/wiki/Verizon_Wireless "Verizon
Wireless") in the United States, available separately from the
[AT&T](/wiki/AT%26T_Mobility "AT&T Mobility") capable version.[90]

The iPad up to the 4th generation uses a Micro-SIM, while the first generation
iPad Mini uses a nano-SIM as introduced with the iPhone 5. The iPad mini is
available with two different frequency bands worldwide. Both devices support
the same quad-band GSM and quad-band UMTS frequencies, but one variant also
supports LTE bands 4 and 17 (principally intended for use on the U.S. AT&T
network), while the other adds support for
[LTE](/wiki/LTE_\(telecommunication\) "LTE \(telecommunication\)") bands 1, 3,
5, 13, 25 and CDMA EV-DO Rev. A and Rev. B.

The 5th generation iPad and 2nd generation iPad mini introduced support for
many additional LTE bands worldwide. The iPad Air and Mini with Retina display
cellular models come in two variants each, all of which support nano-SIMs,
quad-band GSM, penta-band UMTS, and dual-band CDMA EV-DO Rev. A and B.
Additionally, one variant of each iPad also supports LTE bands 1, 2, 3, 4, 5,
7, 8, 13, 17, 18, 19, 20, 25 and 26 while the other variant supports LTE bands
1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 18, 19, 20 and [TD-LTE](/wiki/Time-Division_Long-
Term_Evolution "Time-Division Long-Term Evolution") bands 38, 39 and 40.
Apple's ability to handle many different bands in one device allowed it to
offer, for the first time, a single iPad variant which supports all the
cellular bands and technologies deployed by all the major North American
wireless providers at the time of the device's introduction. Moreover, with
T-Mobile USA selling the iPad Air and Mini with Retina display, these models
became the first iPads that were made available for purchase directly from all
four nationwide U.S. wireless carriers (and, as previously indicated, with all
U.S. carriers now selling the same hardware variant of the device).

### Accessories

Main article: [iPad accessories](/wiki/IPad_accessories "IPad accessories")

Apple offers several iPad accessories,[91] most of which are adapters for the
proprietary 30-pin [dock connector](/wiki/Dock_connector "Dock connector"),
the iPad's only port besides the headphone jack.[13] A dock holds the iPad
upright at an angle, and has a dock connector and audio line out port. Each
generation of iPad requires a corresponding dock. A dock that included a
physical keyboard was only supported for the original iPad,[92] but all
generations are compatible with Bluetooth keyboards that also work with
[Macs](/wiki/Macintosh "Macintosh") and [PCs](/wiki/Personal_computer
"Personal computer"). The iPad can be charged by a standalone power adapter
("wall charger") also used for iPods and iPhones, and a 10 W charger is
included with the iPad.

Apple sells a camera connection kit that consists of two separate adapters for
the dock connector, one to [USB](/wiki/USB "USB") Type A, the other an
[SD](/wiki/Secure_Digital "Secure Digital") card reader. Adapter can be used
to transfer photos and videos and to plug USB [audio
card](/wiki/USB_sound_card "USB sound card") or [MIDI
keyboard](/wiki/MIDI_keyboard "MIDI keyboard").[93] A third party sells an
adapter that includes USB, SD, and [microSD](/wiki/MicroSD "MicroSD") on a
single unit.[94] An adapter to [VGA connectors](/wiki/VGA_connector "VGA
connector") allows the iPad to work with external monitors and projectors.
Another adapter mirrors the screen onto [HDMI](/wiki/HDMI "HDMI") compatible
devices in 1080p and works with all apps and rotations. Unlike other adapters,
it allows the iPad to charge through another dock connector.[95] While the
HDMI adapter was released with and advertised for the [second generation
iPad](/wiki/IPad_\(second_generation\) "IPad \(second generation\)"), it also
works with the first-generation iPad, the [iPhone 4](/wiki/IPhone_4 "IPhone
4"), and the fourth generation iPod Touch.[96]

Smart Covers are screen protectors that magnetically attach and align to the
face of the iPad 2, 3, or 4. The cover has three folds which allow it to
convert into a stand, which is also held together by magnets.[97] While
original iPad owners could purchase a black case that included a similarly
folding cover, the Smart Cover is meant to be more minimal, easily detachable,
and protects only the screen. Smart Covers have a
[microfiber](/wiki/Microfiber "Microfiber") bottom that cleans the front of
the iPad (which wakes up when the cover is removed). There are five different
colors of both polyurethane and leather, with leather being more expensive.
Smart Covers are not compatible with the original iPad.[98] In June 2012,
Apple started selling the Smart Case - a case with the combined function of a
smart cover and a back protection case which is compatible with the iPad 2,
and iPad 3rd & 4th generation devices.[99]

## Software

Main articles: [iOS](/wiki/IOS "IOS") and [iOS version
history](/wiki/IOS_version_history "IOS version history")

Like the iPhone, with which it shares a [development
environment](/wiki/Development_environment_\(software_development_process\)
"Development environment \(software development process\)")[100] the iPad only
runs its own software, software downloaded from Apple's [App
Store](/wiki/App_Store_\(iOS\) "App Store \(iOS\)"), and software written by
developers who have paid for a developer's license on registered
devices.[101][_[not in citation given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] The iPad runs almost all third-party [iPhone
applications](/wiki/IPhone_applications "IPhone applications"), displaying
them at iPhone size or enlarging them to fill the iPad's screen.[102]
Developers may also create or modify apps to take advantage of the iPad's
features,[103] and there are one million apps optimized for the iPad, as of
March 2016.[104] Application developers use iOS SDK for developing
applications for iPad.[105] The iPad originally shipped with a customized
iPad-only version of iPhone OS, dubbed v3.2. On September 1, it was announced
the iPad would get iOS 4.2 by November 2010;[106] to fulfill this Apple
released iOS 4.2.1 to the public on November 22.[107]

### Interface

The [interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface") is
centred around the home screen, a graphical list of available applications.
The home screen can be accessed at any time by a hardware button below the
screen, closing an open application in the process.[108]

Users can also add and delete icons from the dock, which is the same on every
home screen. Each home screen holds up to twenty icons, and the dock holds up
to six icons. Users can delete Web Clips and third-party applications at any
time, and may select only certain applications for transfer from iTunes.
Apple's default programs, however, may not be removed.

Almost all input is given through the touch screen, which understands complex
gestures using [multi-touch](/wiki/Multi-touch "Multi-touch"). The iPad's
[interaction techniques](/wiki/Interaction_technique "Interaction technique")
enable the user to move the content up or down by a touch-drag motion of the
finger. For example, zooming in and out of web pages and photos is done by
placing two fingers on the screen and spreading them farther apart or bringing
them closer together, a gesture known as "[pinching](/wiki/Multi-touch "Multi-
touch")".

Scrolling through a long list or menu is achieved by sliding a finger over the
display from bottom to top, or vice versa to go back. In either case, the list
moves as if it is pasted on the outer surface of a wheel, slowly decelerating
as if affected by friction. In this way, the interface simulates the physics
of a real object.

Other [user-centered](/wiki/User-centered_design "User-centered design")
[interactive](/wiki/Interactive_design "Interactive design") effects include
horizontally sliding sub-selection, the vertically sliding keyboard and
bookmarks menu, and widgets that turn around to allow settings to be
configured on the other side. Menu bars are found at the top and bottom of the
screen when necessary. Their options vary by program, but always follow a
consistent style motif. In menu hierarchies, a "back" button in the top-left
corner of the screen displays the name of the parent folder.

### Multimedia

The layout of the music library is similar to an [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod") or
current [Symbian](/wiki/Symbian "Symbian")
[S60](/wiki/S60_\(software_platform\) "S60 \(software platform\)") phones. The
iPad can sort its media library by songs, artists, albums, videos,
[playlists](/wiki/Playlist "Playlist"), [genres](/wiki/Genre "Genre"),
composers, [podcasts](/wiki/Podcast "Podcast"), [audiobooks](/wiki/Audiobook
"Audiobook"), and [compilations](/wiki/Compilation_album "Compilation album").
Options are always presented alphabetically, except in playlists, which retain
their order from [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes"). The iPhone uses a large font
that allows users plenty of room to touch their selection.

Users can rotate their device horizontally to [landscape
mode](/wiki/Page_orientation "Page orientation") to access [Cover
Flow](/wiki/Cover_Flow "Cover Flow"), likewise this feature may be disabled if
purposely wishing to view a screen from another angle. Like on iTunes, this
feature shows the different album covers in a scroll-through photo library.
Scrolling is achieved by swiping a finger across the screen. Alternatively,
headset controls can be used to pause, play, skip, and repeat tracks.

The iPad supports [gapless playback](/wiki/Gapless_playback "Gapless
playback").[109] Like the [fifth-generation
iPods](/wiki/IPod_Classic#Fifth_generation "IPod Classic") introduced in 2005,
the iPad can play [digital video](/wiki/Digital_video "Digital video"),
allowing users to watch TV shows and movies in [widescreen](/wiki/Widescreen
"Widescreen"). Double-tapping switches between widescreen and
[fullscreen](/wiki/4:3 "4:3") video playback.

The iPad allows users to purchase and download songs from the iTunes Store
directly to their iPad. It includes software that allows the user to upload,
view, and email photos taken with the camera. The user zooms in and out of
photos by sliding two fingers further apart or closer together, much like
Safari. The Camera application also lets users view the camera roll, the
pictures that have been taken with the iPad's camera. Those pictures are also
available in the Photos application, along with any transferred from
[iPhoto](/wiki/IPhoto "IPhoto") or [Aperture](/wiki/Aperture_\(software\)
"Aperture \(software\)") on a Mac, or [Photoshop](/wiki/Adobe_Photoshop "Adobe
Photoshop") on a Windows [PC](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer").

### Internet connectivity

The iPad can use Wi-Fi network [trilateration](/wiki/Trilateration
"Trilateration") from [Skyhook Wireless](/wiki/Skyhook_Wireless "Skyhook
Wireless") to provide location information to applications such as [Google
Maps](/wiki/Google_Maps "Google Maps"). The 3G model supports
[A-GPS](/wiki/Assisted_GPS "Assisted GPS") to allow its position to be
calculated with GPS or relative to nearby cellphone towers; it also has a
black strip on the back to aid 3G reception.[110] The iPad has a [headphone
jack](/wiki/Phone_connector_\(audio\) "Phone connector \(audio\)") and a
proprietary Apple [dock connector](/wiki/Dock_connector "Dock connector"), but
no [Ethernet](/wiki/Ethernet "Ethernet") or USB port.[13] However, the Apple
Camera Connection Kit accessory provides two dock connector adapters for
importing photos and videos via USB and SD memory cards.

### Applications

The iPad comes with several applications, including Safari, Mail, Photos,
Video, iPod, [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes"), App Store, [iBooks](/wiki/IBooks
"IBooks"), [Maps](/wiki/Apple_Maps "Apple Maps"), Notes, Calendar, and
Contacts.[111] Several are improved versions of applications developed for the
iPhone or [Mac](/wiki/Macintosh "Macintosh").

The iPad syncs with iTunes on a Mac or Windows PC.[25] Apple ported its
[iWork](/wiki/IWork "IWork") suite from the Mac to the iPad, and sells pared
down versions of [Pages](/wiki/Pages_\(word_processor\) "Pages \(word
processor\)"), [Numbers](/wiki/Numbers_\(spreadsheet\) "Numbers
\(spreadsheet\)"), and [Keynote](/wiki/Keynote_\(presentation_software\)
"Keynote \(presentation software\)") apps in the App Store.[112] Although the
iPad is not designed to replace a mobile phone, a user can use a wired headset
or the built-in speaker and microphone and place telephone calls over Wi-Fi or
3G using a [VoIP](/wiki/VoIP "VoIP") application.[113] As of June 2012, there
were about 225,000 iPad specific apps on the App Store.[114]

In December 2010, Reuters reported that iPhone and iPad users have lodged a
lawsuit against Apple alleging that some applications were passing their
information to third party advertisers without consent.[115]

### iBooks

Further information: [iBookstore](/wiki/IBookstore "IBookstore")

The iPad has an optional [iBooks](/wiki/IBooks "IBooks") application that can
be downloaded from the App Store, which displays books and other
[ePub](/wiki/EPub "EPub")-format content downloaded from the
[iBookstore](/wiki/IBookstore "IBookstore").[116] For the iPad launch on April
3, 2010, the iBookstore is available only in the United States.[2][25] Several
major book publishers including Penguin Books, HarperCollins, Simon & Schuster
and Macmillan have committed to publishing books for the iPad.[117] Despite
its being a direct competitor to both the [Amazon Kindle](/wiki/Amazon_Kindle
"Amazon Kindle") and [Barnes & Noble Nook](/wiki/Barnes_%26_Noble_Nook "Barnes
& Noble Nook"),[118] both [Amazon.com](/wiki/Amazon.com "Amazon.com") and
[Barnes & Noble](/wiki/Barnes_%26_Noble "Barnes & Noble") have made Kindle and
Nook apps available for the iPad.[119][120]

In February 2010, [Condé Nast](/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast "Condé Nast") said it
would sell iPad subscriptions for several of its magazines by June.[121]

In April 2010, _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_ announced that it would begin publishing daily on the iPad.[122] The
"Top News" section is available free of charge, and the remainder on payment
of a [subscription](/wiki/Subscription_business_model "Subscription business
model").[123] Major news organizations, including _[The Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ , the
[BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"), and [Reuters](/wiki/Reuters "Reuters") have released
iPad applications. [NewsCorp](/wiki/NewsCorp "NewsCorp") created an iPad-only
publication, _[The Daily](/wiki/The_Daily_\(News_Corporation\) "The Daily
\(News Corporation\)")_ , in February 2011.[124] It ceased operations in
December 2012.

The iPad is assembled by [Foxconn](/wiki/Foxconn "Foxconn"), which also
manufactures Apple's iPod, iPhone and Mac Mini, in its largest plant in
[Shenzhen](/wiki/Shenzhen "Shenzhen"), China,[157][158] and by
[Pegatron](/wiki/Pegatron "Pegatron") in [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai
"Shanghai"), China.[159][160] In April 2011, Foxconn announced that it would
be moving production of the iPad and other Apple products to Brazil where it
could begin production before the end of 2011.[161]

iSuppli estimated that each first-generation iPad 16 GB Wi-Fi version costs
US$259.60 to manufacture, a total that excludes research, development,
licensing, royalty and patent costs.[162] Apple does not disclose the makers
of iPad components, but [teardown](/wiki/Product_teardown "Product teardown")
reports and analysis from industry insiders indicate that various parts and
their suppliers include:

  * [Apple A4](/wiki/Apple_A4 "Apple A4"), A5 and A5X [SoC](/wiki/System_on_a_chip "System on a chip"): [Samsung](/wiki/Samsung "Samsung").[13][163][164][165]
  * NAND flash RAM chips: [Toshiba](/wiki/Toshiba "Toshiba") and [Samsung](/wiki/Samsung "Samsung") (64 GB model).[166][167]
  * Touch-screen chips: [Broadcom](/wiki/Broadcom "Broadcom").[166]
  * IPS Display (1st & 2nd generation): [LG Display](/wiki/LG_Display "LG Display").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * IPS Display (3rd generation): [Samsung](/wiki/Samsung "Samsung").[168]
  * Touch panels: [Wintek](/wiki/Wintek "Wintek") (after TPK Touch Solutions was unable to fulfill its orders, delaying the iPad's release from late March to early April).[169]
  * Case: Catcher Technologies.[170]
  * Batteries: 60% are made in Taiwan by Simplo Technology, 40% by Dynapack International.[80][170]
  * Accelerometer: [STMicroelectronics](/wiki/STMicroelectronics "STMicroelectronics").[171]

## Restrictions

### Digital rights management

For more details on the digital rights management restrictions, see [iOS
(Apple) § Digital rights
management](/wiki/IOS_\(Apple\)#Digital_rights_management "IOS \(Apple\)").

The iPad does not employ [digital rights
management](/wiki/Digital_rights_management "Digital rights management")
(DRM), but the OS prevents users from copying or transferring certain content
outside of Apple's platform without authorization, such as TV shows, movies,
and apps. Also, the iPad's development model requires anyone creating an app
for the iPad to sign a [non-disclosure agreement](/wiki/Non-
disclosure_agreement "Non-disclosure agreement") and pay for a developer
subscription. Critics argue Apple's centralized app approval process and
control of the platform itself could stifle software innovation. Of particular
concern to [digital rights](/wiki/Digital_rights "Digital rights") advocates
is Apple's ability to remotely disable or delete apps on any iPad at any
time.[183][184][185]

Digital rights advocates, including the [Free Software
Foundation](/wiki/Free_Software_Foundation "Free Software Foundation"),[186]
[Electronic Frontier Foundation](/wiki/Electronic_Frontier_Foundation
"Electronic Frontier Foundation"),[185] and computer engineer and activist
[Brewster Kahle](/wiki/Brewster_Kahle "Brewster Kahle"),[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] have
criticized the iPad for its digital rights restrictions. In April 2010, Paul
Sweeting, an analyst with [GigaOM](/wiki/GigaOM "GigaOM"), was quoted by
_National Public Radio_ as saying, "With the iPad, you have the anti-Internet
in your hands. ... It offers [the major media companies] the opportunity to
essentially re-create the old business model, wherein they are pushing content
to you on their terms rather than you going out and finding content, or a
search engine discovering content for you." But Sweeting also thought that the
limitations imposed by Apple impart the feeling of a safe neighborhood,
saying, "Apple is offering you a gated community where there's a guard at the
gate, and there's probably maid service, too." [Laura
Sydell](/wiki/Laura_Sydell "Laura Sydell"), the article's author, concludes,
"As more consumers have fears about security on the Internet, viruses and
malware, they may be happy to opt for Apple's gated community."[187] The
Russian government has switched from iPads to Android devices over security
concerns.[188]

### Jailbreaking

For more details on iPad jailbreaking, see [iOS
jailbreaking](/wiki/IOS_jailbreaking "IOS jailbreaking").

Like certain iOS devices, the iPad can be "jailbroken", depending on which
version of [iOS](/wiki/IOS "IOS") it is running, thus allowing applications
and programs that are not authorized by Apple to run on the device.[189][190]
Once it is jailbroken, users are able to download many applications previously
unavailable through the App Store via unofficial installers such as
[Cydia](/wiki/Cydia "Cydia"), as well as illegally
[pirated](/wiki/Copyright_infringement_of_software "Copyright infringement of
software") applications.[190] Apple claims jailbreaking "can" void the factory
warranty on the device in the United States even though jailbreaking is
legal.[190][191] The iPad, released in April 2010, was first jailbroken in May
2010 with the
[Spirit](/w/index.php?title=Spirit_\(iOS_jailbreak\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Spirit \(iOS jailbreak\) \(page does not exist\)") jailbreak for iOS version
3.1.2.[192] The iPad can be jailbroken on iOS versions 4.3 through 4.3.3 with
the web-based tool [JailbreakMe](/wiki/JailbreakMe "JailbreakMe") 3.0
(released in July 2011),[193] and on iOS versions including 5.0 and 5.0.1
using [redsn0w](/wiki/Redsn0w "Redsn0w")[194] Absinthe 2.0 was released on May
25, 2012 as the first jailbreak method for all iOS 5.1.1 devices except the 32
nm version of the iPad 2.[195]

### Censorship

Apple's App Store, which provides iPhone and iPad applications, imposes
censorship of content, which has become an issue for book publishers and
magazines seeking to use the platform. _The Guardian_ newspaper described the
role of Apple as analogous to that of British magazine distributor [WH
Smith](/wiki/WH_Smith "WH Smith"), which for many years imposed content
restrictions.[196]

Due to the exclusion of pornography from the App Store,
[YouPorn](/wiki/YouPorn "YouPorn") and others changed their video format from
[Flash](/wiki/Adobe_Flash#Flash_Video "Adobe Flash") to [H.264](/wiki/H.264
"H.264") and [HTML5](/wiki/HTML5 "HTML5") specifically for the iPad.[197] In
an e-mail exchange[198] with Ryan Tate from [Valleywag](/wiki/Valleywag
"Valleywag"), Steve Jobs claimed that the iPad offers "freedom from porn",
leading to many upset replies including [Adbustings](/wiki/Adbusting
"Adbusting") in Berlin by artist Johannes P. Osterhoff[199] and in San
Francisco during [WWDC10](/wiki/Worldwide_Developers_Conference#WWDC_2010
"Worldwide Developers Conference").[200]

## Reception

On May 28, 2010, the iPad was released in Australia, Canada, and Japan, as
well as in several larger [European](/wiki/European_Union "European Union")
countries. Media reaction to the launch was mixed. The media noted the
positive response from fans of the device, with thousands of people queued on
the first day of sale in a number of these countries.[201][202]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Deathpad_protest_%284710950216%29.jpg/200px-
Deathpad_protest_%284710950216%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Deathpad_protest_\(4710950216\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Deathpad_protest_\(4710950216\).jpg "Enlarge")

Protesters of manufacturing conditions of the iPad in [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") in 2010

### Reaction to the announcement

Media reaction to the iPad announcement was mixed. [Walter
Mossberg](/wiki/Walter_Mossberg "Walter Mossberg") wrote, "It's about the
software, stupid", meaning hardware features and build are less important to
the iPad's success than software and user interface, his first impressions of
which were largely positive. Mossberg also called the price "modest" for a
device of its capabilities, and praised the ten-hour battery life.[203]
Others, including _PC Advisor_ and the _Sydney Morning Herald_ , wrote that
the iPad would also compete with proliferating [netbooks](/wiki/Netbook
"Netbook"), most of which use [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows
"Microsoft Windows").[204][205] The base model's $499 price was lower than
pre-release estimates by the tech press, [Wall Street](/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall
Street") analysts, and Apple's competitors, all of whom were expecting a much
higher entry price point.[206][207][208]

_[CNET](/wiki/CNET "CNET")_ also criticized the iPad for its apparent lack of
wireless sync which other portable devices such as Microsoft's
[Zune](/wiki/Zune "Zune") have had for a number of years. The built-in iTunes
app is able to download from the [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet") as
well.[209]

### Reviews

Reviews of the iPad have been generally favorable. [Walt
Mossberg](/wiki/Walt_Mossberg "Walt Mossberg") then, of _[The Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ called it a
"pretty close" laptop killer.[210] [David Pogue](/wiki/David_Pogue "David
Pogue") of _The New York Times_ wrote a "dual" review, one part for
technology-minded people, and the other part for non-technology-minded people.
In the former section, he notes that a laptop offers more features for a
cheaper price than the iPad. In his review for the latter audience, however,
he claims that if his readers like the concept of the device and can
understand what its intended uses are, then they will enjoy using the
device.[211] [PC Magazine](/wiki/PC_Magazine "PC Magazine")'s Tim Gideon
wrote, "you have yourself a winner" that "will undoubtedly be a driving force
in shaping the emerging tablet landscape."[212] Michael Arrington of
_[TechCrunch](/wiki/TechCrunch "TechCrunch")_ said, "the iPad beats even my
most optimistic expectations. This is a new category of device. But it also
will replace laptops for many people."[213] [PC World](/wiki/PC_World "PC
World") criticized the iPad's [file sharing](/wiki/File_sharing "File
sharing") and printing abilities,[214] and _[Ars Technica](/wiki/Ars_Technica
"Ars Technica")_ said sharing files with a computer is "one of our least
favorite parts of the iPad experience."[215]

The media also praised the quantity of applications, as well as the bookstore
and other media applications.[216][217] In contrast they criticized the iPad
for being a closed system and mentioned that the iPad faces competition from
[Android](/wiki/Android_\(operating_system\) "Android \(operating
system\)")-based tablets,[201] that outsold iPads in 2013, surpassing iPads in
the second quarter of 2013,[218] and have overtaken iPad's installed
base,[219] and has lost majority of web browsing to Android, by
[StatCounter](/wiki/StatCounter "StatCounter") estimates, in [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America"), Africa, most of Asia – many
large countries there and in Eastern Europe.[220] _The Independent_ criticized
the iPad for not being as readable in bright light as paper but praised it for
being able to store large quantities of books.[216] After its
[UK](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") release, _The Daily Telegraph_
said the iPad's lack of [Adobe Flash](/wiki/Adobe_Flash "Adobe Flash") support
was "annoying."[221]

### Recognition

The iPad was selected by _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_
magazine as one of the 50 Best Inventions of the Year 2010,[222] while
[Popular Science](/wiki/Popular_Science "Popular Science") chose it as the top
gadget[223] behind the overall "Best of What's New 2010" winner [Groasis
Waterboxx](/wiki/Groasis_Waterboxx "Groasis Waterboxx").[224]

## Usage

### Market share

iPad tablets still have a wide margin globally on second most used Android
tablets. The market share, however, differs widely by regions; and the iPad
has lost market share globally, every year since 2012 (when StatCounter
started tracking tablets separately).[225]

According to [StatCounter](/wiki/StatCounter "StatCounter") statistics, that
tracks web use and gives operating system/platform share based on it, the iPad
has lost majority of use in South America to Android,[226][227] did also lose
majority while gaining back in Asia[228] and in Africa has lost by a wide
margin, where Android is up to 70%.[229]

### Business

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/541e914bc5a3e56d405d5bee513e758e.png)

While the iPad is mostly used by consumers, it also has been taken up by
business users.[230] Within 90 days of its release, the iPad managed to
penetrate 50% of Fortune 100 companies.[231] Some companies are adopting iPads
in their business offices by distributing or making available iPads to
employees. Examples of uses in the workplace include attorneys responding to
clients, medical professionals accessing health records during patient exams,
and managers approving employee requests.[232][233][234]

A survey by [Frost & Sullivan](/wiki/Frost_%26_Sullivan "Frost & Sullivan")
shows that iPad usage in office workplaces is linked to the goals of increased
employee productivity, reduced paperwork, and increased revenue. The research
firm estimates that "The mobile-office application market in North America may
reach $6.85 billion in 2015, up from an estimated $1.76 billion [in
2010]."[235]

Since March 2011, the US [Federal Aviation
Administration](/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration "Federal Aviation
Administration") has approved the iPad for in-cockpit use to cut down on the
paper consumption in several airlines.[236] In 2011, [Alaska
Airlines](/wiki/Alaska_Airlines "Alaska Airlines") became the first airline to
replace pilots' paper manuals with iPads, weighing 0.68 kg compared to 11 kg
for the printed flight manuals. It hopes to have fewer back and muscle
injuries.[237] More than a dozen airlines have followed suit, including
United, which has distributed 11,000 iPads to cockpits.[238] Also, many
airlines now offer their inflight magazine as a downloadable application for
the iPad.[239][240][241]

### Education and healthcare

The iPad has several uses in the classroom,[242] and has been praised as a
valuable tool for homeschooling.[243][244] Soon after the iPad was released,
it was reported that 81% of the top book apps were for children.[245] The iPad
has also been called a revolutionary tool to help children with autism learn
how to communicate and socialize more easily.[246]

In the healthcare field, iPads and iPhones have been used to help hospitals
manage their [supply chain](/wiki/Supply_chain_management "Supply chain
management"). For example, Novation, a healthcare contracting services
company, developed VHA PriceLynx (based on the mobile application platform of
business intelligence software vendor MicroStrategy), a [business
intelligence](/wiki/Business_intelligence "Business intelligence") app to help
health care organizations manage its purchasing procedures more efficiently
and save money for hospitals. Guillermo Ramas of Novation states, "Doctors
won't walk around a hospital with a laptop. With an iPad it's perfect to walk
around the hospital with as long as they have the information they need."[247]

In 2013, Gianna Chien (aged 14) presented to more than 8,000 doctors at the
Heart Rhythm Society meeting that Apple iPad 2 can, in some cases, interfere
with life-saving heart devices (pace maker) because of the magnets
inside.[248] Apple's webpage has advised pacemaker users to keep iPads at
least 6-inches away from the pacemaker.

### Consumer usage

In the United States, fans attending [Super Bowl XLV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV
"Super Bowl XLV"), the first Super Bowl since the iPad was released, could use
an official [National Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League
"National Football League") (NFL) app to navigate [Cowboys
Stadium](/wiki/Cowboys_Stadium "Cowboys Stadium").[249] In 2011, the [Tampa
Bay Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers "Tampa Bay Buccaneers") became the
first NFL club to discontinue the use of paper copies of playbooks, and
instead distributed all players their playbook and videos in electronic format
via an [iPad 2](/wiki/IPad_2 "IPad 2").[250]

The iPad is able to support many music creation applications in addition to
the iTunes music playback software. These include sound samplers, guitar and
voice effects processors, sequencers for synthesized sounds and sampled loops,
virtual synthesizers and drum machines, theremin-style and other touch
responsive instruments, drum pads and many more. [Gorillaz](/wiki/Gorillaz
"Gorillaz")'s 2010 album, _[The Fall](/wiki/The_Fall_\(Gorillaz_album\) "The
Fall \(Gorillaz album\)")_ , was created almost exclusively using the iPad by
[Damon Albarn](/wiki/Damon_Albarn "Damon Albarn") while on tour with the
band.[251] The music video for [Luna Sea](/wiki/Luna_Sea "Luna Sea")'s 2012
single, "[Rouge](/wiki/The_End_of_the_Dream/Rouge "The End of the
Dream/Rouge")", was filmed entirely on an iPad.[252]

The iPad has also greatly increased [social
television](/wiki/Social_television "Social television") use. Viewers can use
the iPad as a convenient second networked computer (or "[second
screen](/wiki/Second_screen "Second screen")") for communicating with other
viewers or with the television provider. Viewers can use a web browser or
specialised applications to discuss a program with other viewers, while it is
being broadcast, while content providers may use the second screen to interact
with viewers in real time. For example, the latter facility allows content
providers to conduct real-time polls or to collect comments about the program,
that can be displayed as text on the main television screen. Viewer
interaction via a second screen is becoming increasingly popular.[253]
